Let $a_1,\ldots,a_p$ be (not necessarily distinct) residues modulo $p$, such that there exists some $r$ so that if $S\subseteq [p]$ is non-empty and\[\sum_{i\in S}a_i\equiv 0\pmod{p}\]then $\lvert S\rvert=r$. Must there be at most two distinct residues amongst the $a_i$?



A question of Graham. This was proved by Erd\H{o}s and Szemer\'{e}di \cite{ErSz76} for $p$ sufficiently large and by Gao, Hamidoune, and Wang \cite{GHW10} for all moduli (not necessarily prime).




References


[ErSz76] Erd\H{o}s, E. and Szemer\'{e}di, E., On a problem of Graham. Publ. Math. Debrecen (1976), 123--127.

[GHW10] Gao, Weidong and Hamidoune, Yahya Ould and Wang, Guoqing, Distinct length modular zero-sum subsequences: a proof of
Graham's conjecture. J. Number Theory (2010), 1425--1431.
